title: 114_s614
content: The "Federal Improper Payments Coordination Act of 2015" allows the judicial and legislative branches, states, and related entities access to the Do Not Pay Initiative for preventing improper payments. The Do Not Pay Initiative can be accessed by states, contractors, subcontractors, and agents for verifying payment eligibility. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget determines the establishment of the Initiative for states, contractors, subcontractors, and agents. The judicial and legislative branches can also access the Initiative if the Director determines its appropriate establishment for them. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may issue guidance for the Do Not Pay Initiative access agreements with States, contractors, subcontractors, and agents, ensuring consistency with the Privacy Act of 1974. This guidance may also include States and their quasi-government entities. SEC. 3. IMPROVING THE SHARING AND USE OF DATA BY GOVERNMENT AGENCIES TO CURB IMPROPER PAYMENTS. The Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 is amended to include the prompt reporting of death information by the Department of Social Security. The Secretary of State and the Secretary of Defense must establish a procedure to report death information to relevant agencies to prevent improper payments. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide guidance on data access and use for this purpose. The heads of relevant agencies will issue guidance on implementing the Do Not Pay Initiative to agencies operating databases or needing improved data matching. The guidance will address implementation and set deadlines for database access under the initiative. The Do Not Pay Initiative includes data analytics for detecting, preventing, and recovering improper payments through various analyses. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Federal Improper Payments Coordination Act of 2015 enactment, detailing the analytics conducted by the Do Not Pay Business Center. The Do Not Pay Initiative involves data analytics to identify and prevent improper payments. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on the analytics conducted by the Do Not Pay Business Center, including reviews of State programs, Federal agencies, and other relevant information to reduce improper payments. Metrics are used to assess the effectiveness of these efforts. The Do Not Pay Business Center conducts data analytics to prevent improper payments and awards, with target dates for implementing these operations.
